A Computer-generated video is being falsely shared as real footage of an asteroid hitting the Moon
==================================================================================================
By  on September 8, 2023
*        
A  allegedly showing an asteroid hitting the Moon’s surface has gone viral on social media. Let’s fact-check this video through this article.
!
> **Claim:** This footage shows an asteroid striking the Moon’s surface.  
>   
> **Fact:** This is a Computer-generated video; it does not show actual footage of an asteroid hitting the Moon’s surface. Hence, the claim made in the post is **False**.
Firstly, we searched the internet to see if the media reported any such incident. However, this did not lead us to any credible sources.
To learn more details about the viral clip, we performed a reverse image search using a few of its keyframes. This search led us to an Instagram post containing the  (flipped on its vertical axis), credited to a social media user named “_diego.sinclair._” Uploaded by a page named  _(they upload space and astronomy-related videos),_ this video has been described as a CGI (Computed Generated Imagery) video.
!
Searching for _diego.sinclair_ on the internet led us to a YouTube channel that contained the  (This channel also contains ). Diego has mentioned in the comments that this is an edited video. Replying to a user’s comment who expressed their skepticism on the video, he said, _“It’s just an edit, but explosions from impacts do happen on the moon.”_ This makes it clear that it is an edited video, and the visuals do not represent an actual asteroid striking the Moon.
!
A further search on the Internet to investigate whether such incidents were captured on the Moon recently revealed (,  and ) that a man named _“Daichi Fujii, curator of the Hiratsuka City Museum, captured a meteor hitting the moon, triggering a brief flash on the surface.”_
> 私の観測史上最大の月面衝�...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Factly is an Indian fact-checking website that aims to counter misinformation by examining and validating claims. While it has a useful function and investigates various topics, its reach and resources are not as extensive as larger fact-checkers like AFP. Its value can be context-dependent, depending on the specific claims it covers.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence confirms that the video was CGI and directly tackles the viral claims regarding it as real footage. It provides substantial support to label the original claim as false, similar to previous strong evidence.

Scientists at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center at the Automated Lunar and Meteor Observatory (ALaMO) in Huntsville, Ala., capture lunar impact flash video caused by such strikes several times a month. NASA is studying these impacts to help safeguard future lunar explorers and long-term science missions to the moon. (NASA)

It is known for its rigorous scientific research, transparent data collection, and publishing on various aspects of space, including lunar studies and impacts. The information provided by NASA is consistently trustworthy, accurate, and peer-reviewed, making it a gold standard source for information related to space and astronomy.

A Japanese astronomer captured the telltale flash of a meteorite impacting the moon, causing a brief flash on our celestial neighbor's nightside.
Daichi Fujii, curator of the Hiratsuka City Museum, recorded the event using cameras set to monitor .
The time of the flash was 20:14:30.8 Japan Standard Time (7:14 a.m. EST, or 1114 GMT) on Feb. 23. The  appears to have struck near Ideler L crater, slightly northwest of Pitiscus crater, Fujii said.
**Related:** 
!
Japanese astronomer Daichi Fujii captured this shot of a meteorite impacting the moon (bright flash at bottom left) on Feb. 23, 2023.  (Image credit: Daichi Fujii (Hiratsuka City Museum))
TOP TELESCOPE PICK:
!
(Image credit: Celestron)
Need a telescope to see the moon up close? We recommend the  as the top pick in our .
Meteors travel  at around 30,000 mph (48,280 kph), or 8.3 miles per second (13.4 km/s). Their high-velocity impacts generate intense heat and create craters, while also giving out a brilliant flash of visible light. Moon impacts can be seen from Earth, as captured above, if they are large enough and occur in an area during lunar nighttime facing Earth.
The newly created crater could be around a dozen meters (39 feet) in diameter and may eventually be imaged by 's  or India's Chandrayaan 2 lunar probe, Fujii said.

Query2.title: Apollo landing footage would have been impossible to fake. A film ...
Query2.snippet: Jul 10, 2019 ... A common theory is that film director Stanley Kubrick helped NASA fake the historic footage of its six successful moon landings. But would ...

content.content:
Howard Berry, The Conversation


                    Howard Berry, The Conversation
                

It’s been half a century since the magnificent Apollo 11 moon landing, yet many people still don’t believe it actually happened. Conspiracy theories about the event dating back to the 1970s are in fact more popular than ever. A common theory is that film director Stanley Kubrick helped NASA fake the historic footage of its six successful moon landings.
But would it really have been possible to do that with the technology available at the time? 
I’m not a space travel expert, an engineer or a scientist. I am a filmmaker and lecturer in film post-production, and – while I can’t say how we landed on the moon in 1969 – I can say with some certainty that the footage would have been impossible to fake.
Here are some of the most common beliefs and questions – and why they don’t hold up.
There are two different ways of capturing moving images. One is film, actual strips of photographic material onto which a series of images are exposed. Another is video, which is an electronic method of recording onto various mediums, such as moving magnetic tape. With video, you can also broadcast to a television receiver. A standard motion picture film records images at 24 frames per second, while broadcast television is typically either 25 or 30 frames, depending on where you are in the world.
READ MORE: How many people does it take to keep a conspiracy alive?
If we go along with the idea that the moon landings were taped in a TV studio, then we would expect them to be 30 frames per second video, which...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: PBS is a well-respected public broadcasting service in the United States known for its educational programming and in-depth journalism. It has a reputation for fact-based reporting and provides a wealth of information related to science, history, and current affairs. Its pieces often involve research and expert opinions, which helps in maintaining high credibility. However, as with any media outlet, the potential for bias depending on the topic can reduce the score slightly.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses the authenticity of Apollo landing footage and the challenges of faking such footage with the technology of the time. While it touches on the topic of authenticity, it does not specifically address the CGI aspect or provide direct analysis regarding the explosion in the moon video. Thus, its relevance is low but not entirely absent.

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Reddit is a social news aggregation, web content rating, and discussion website. While it contains many valuable user-generated discussions and information, it lacks a formal editorial process, allowing for the spread of misinformation. Its decentralized nature makes it difficult to assess credibility, hence it receives a mid-range score. It can be a place for genuine insights, but critical thinking is necessary when reading posts.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This Reddit post mentions deep fakes and experts in a broad context but doesn't directly address the specific query about moon explosion CGI versus actual footage. Its relevance is minimal.

QA.Question: Is there any expert analysis confirming whether the explosion in the video was created using CGI or actual footage?
QA.Answer: The explosion depicted in the video claiming to show an asteroid hitting the Moon was created using CGI and not actual footage. Here are the reasons supporting this conclusion: 1. **Expert Confirmation of CGI**: A fact-check report specifically states that the video is a computer-generated imagery (CGI) creation and does not represent real footage of an asteroid impacting the Moon. The report indicates that the claim about the video showing an actual impact is false, as corroborated by reverse image searches and confirmations from the creator of the video who described it as an edited video [Query1_evidence_1]. 2. **Lack of Recent Impact Footage**: While it is true that meteoroids do impact the Moon and these events can sometimes be observed, there has been no credible recent footage confirming an asteroid impact similar to what is portrayed in the video. In fact, NASA has a program that monitors lunar impacts, but the video in question does not align with any real events captured by these programs [Query1_evidence_2]. 3. **Actual Impact Recordings**: Previous instances of lunar impacts, such as one captured by astronomer Daichi Fujii in February 2023, demonstrate that while impacts can create observable phenomena (like brief flashes), these are recorded by actual observational equipment and are not CGI [Query1_evidence_3]. The nature of the reported explosion in the video starkly contrasts with real footage from documented lunar impacts.
